paraDialog.line: - Ahmed Rahman:
Good morning.
My name is Mr Rahman, and as you can tell I'm a police officer. I'm the community police officer for this area and I've come to do a special assembly for you this morning about bullying.

Year six has made a list. They've decided all of these things are bullying, especially if you keep doing them. They aren't the same as just being in a bad mood with someone, or feeling cross with them for a while because you've had an argument.
This is the list year six has made
name-calling
spreading rumours about someone
making up stories to get a person into trouble
taking friends away so someone is left on their own
telling other people not to be friends with someone
hitting, kicking, tripping up, or pushing around
being rude about a person's culture, religion or colour
saying nasty things about a person's looks or weight
talking in a bad way about a person's disability or illness
not letting someone be your partner in class
leaving someone out when you're choosing a games team
taking away a person's things, or demanding money from them
damaging someone's things
hiding things like a person's books or bag
making jokes about someone when you know it upsets them
sending nasty text messages, silent phone calls, or nasty emails
making threats that you're going to do something they won't like
All of these things are unpleasant things to happen to you, but I'm here to say two things about them.
The first thing is that part of the job of a community police officer is to make sure things don't get nasty outside of school.
So, if anything like bullying is happening in your street, or on the way home, either from this school or children from another one, then I should be able to help.
The second thing is that these things on your posters are not just nasty, some of them are against the law as well.
